chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of non-complex burns and scalds
chapter.summary: Covers the ongoing management of minor superficial epidermal and dermal burns and scalds in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: First aid and initial management

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage epidermal burns?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For people with suspected superficial epidermal burns (such as sunburn) or scalds:

  • Give advice on sources of information and support, such as the NHS leaflets on Sunburn and Heat exhaustion and heatstroke.
  • Give advice on measures to provide symptom relief, such as:
    • Taking a cool bath or shower.
    • Applying topical emollients, such as emulsifying ointment.
    • Applying cold compresses.
    • Using simple analgesia, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen, if needed. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information.
  • Advise the person to maintain adequate hydration, to help wound healing and reduce the risk of complications.
  • Massage the area daily with an emollient, such as emulsifying ointment, until the burn is no longer dry or itchy.
  • Consider arranging urgent hospital referral if there are signs or symptoms of heat exhaustion or heat stroke, such as:
    • Fatigue, dizziness, nausea or vomiting.
    • Headache, muscle cramps, irritability.
    • Confusion, disorientation, hallucinations.
    • Fever and/or tachycardia.
  • Advise the person to arrange urgent review if blisters develop, as this may suggest progressive dermal injury. See the section on Management of superficial dermal burns for more information on management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are based on expert opinion in the International Best Practice Guideline Effective skin and wound management of non-complex burns [Wounds International, 2014] and expert opinion in a review article on burn dressings [Douglas, 2017].

  • The recommendation on skin care and use of an emollient is to reduce skin dryness and itch [Douglas, 2017].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage superficial dermal burns?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For people with suspected superficial dermal burns and scalds, ensure that appropriate first aid has been given, and that the wound has been fully assessed.

  • Ensure that the burn is suitable for management in primary care and does not require specialist referral.
  • Arrange for appropriate wound cleaning, debridement, blister management, and wound dressing by a person with appropriate expertise and training. See the section on Wound management for more information.
  • Give advice on sources of information and support, such as:
    • The NHS information leaflet on Burns and scalds.
    • Changing Faces (website available at www.changingfaces.org.uk) is a national charity which campaigns to support and empower people living with a disfigurement, and includes a telephone support line (telephone 0300 012 0275), regional centres, self-help guides, and a skin camouflage service.
    • The British Burn Association (website available at www.britishburnassociation.org) is a charity concerned with all aspects of burn care, which has information on burn clubs and camps, and links to other support organisations.
  • Give advice on simple analgesia for symptom relief, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. Consider adding in codeine for more severe pain, if appropriate. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information.
  • Assess the need for tetanus prophylaxis, and manage appropriately.
  • Arrange for the wound to be reassessed:
    • After 48 hours to check for signs of infection (such as increased pain, odour, excessive exudate, fever, erythema, or friable tissue), and change the dressing, if needed. Note: excessive exudate may be a normal clinical finding in the first 72 hours after a burn injury.
    • Every 3–5 days for dressing changes (depending on the type of dressing, amount of exudate, and rate of healing), until the wound is healed.
  • Advise the person to be reviewed urgently if there are new signs of infection. See the section on Management of suspected wound infection for more information.
  • Following wound healing, advise the person on skin care:
    • Massage the area daily with an emollient, such as emulsifying ointment, until the burn is no longer dry or itchy (usually around 3–6 months), to reduce the risk of hypertrophic scarring.
    • Use high factor sunblock (sun protection factor 30–50) or clothing over the affected skin for 1–2 years, to prevent irregular pigmentation or hyperpigmentation.
  • Arrange referral to:
    • A specialist burns unit or seek specialist advice for any wound that is not improving as expected, or that has not healed within two weeks of the initial injury, depending on clinical judgement.
    • A physiotherapist and/or occupational therapist if the person has hypertrophic scars or contractures which need support with maintaining movement and function.
    • A skin camouflage service, if needed.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Wound management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Ensure a professional with appropriate experience and expertise in wound management is involved in the person's care (such as a practice nurse, district nurse, or tissue viability nurse), to optimize wound healing and reduce the risk of infection.

  • Wound cleaning
    • Cleansing is useful for removing foreign bodies, soluble debris, excess slough, or necrotic tissue, which may become a focus for infection.
    • Cleansing is advised prior to obtaining a bacteriology swab (but do not take swabs unless there is clinical evidence of wound infection).
    • If a clean technique is being used, use lukewarm tap water.
    • If a sterile technique is required, use 0.9% normal saline.
    • Ideally, the cleansing fluid should be at body temperature, or if this is not possible, the fluid should be warmed to room temperature before use.
  • Gentle wound irrigation
    • Do not clean wounds by scrubbing, which causes pain and local tissue oedema. Irrigation is more protective of fragile tissue.
    • Do not use topical antiseptics due to reported pain, tissue damage, wound drying, and delayed healing.
  • Gentle debridement
    • Debridement describes the removal of necrotic, devitalized, sloughy, or infected tissue. This allows visualisation of the wound bed and may encourage epithelialization.
    • Natural (autolytic) debridement may be promoted by the use of specialist dressings, such as hydrogels.
    • Note: specialist surgical debridement may be appropriate following referral.
  • Blister management
    • Blisters should be left intact wherever possible, to reduce the risk of infection.
    • Consider de-roofing large blisters (for example, greater than 1 cm2); blisters that are likely to rupture or are over a joint, using an aseptic technique.
  • Wound dressing
    • The choice of dressing will depend on the site, size, and depth of the wound, level of exudate, infection risk, and on local formulary availability.
    • An appropriate size and type of dressing should be selected to avoid stretching or applying dressings under tension.
    • The wound should be covered with a non-adherent dressing, such as paraffin gauze, silicone-coated nylon dressing, polyurethane film, or hydrocolloid dressing.
    • A secondary non-fibrous absorbent dressing such as a dressing pad should then be applied and secured well with a lightweight conforming bandage or tubular gauze bandage.
    • Dressings should be changed regularly to encourage wound healing. Once burn depth is accurately estimated, the frequency of dressing change may be reduced to minimize the risk of bacterial contamination and trauma to the wound. If appropriate, the person or a carer can be supported to change their own dressings.
    • Appropriate analgesia should be taken by the person before dressing changes.
    • Note: do not use systemic or topical prophylactic antibiotics, antimicrobial-impregnated dressings, antimicrobial creams such as silver sulfadiazine, or other topical preparations routinely.

[Butcher, 2012; Kim, 2012; Lloyd, 2012; White, 2012; Barajas-Nava, 2013; Wounds International, 2014; Douglas, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are based on the International Best Practice Guideline Effective skin and wound management of non-complex burns [Wounds International, 2014], the International Society for Burn Injuries (ISBI) Practice guidelines for burn care [ISBI, 2016], the Cochrane systematic reviews Antibiotic prophylaxis for preventing burn wound infection (Review) [Barajas-Nava, 2013], Dressings for superficial and partial thickness burns (Review) [Wasiak, 2013], and Antiseptics for burns (Review) [Norman, 2017], the Public Health England (PHE) document Tetanus: the green book, chapter 30 [PHE, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Butcher, 2012; Cleland, 2012; Lloyd, 2012; White, 2012; Culleiton, 2013; Gnaneswaran, 2015; Douglas, 2017].

Advice on wound management
  • The aim of good wound management is to provide a moist environment to promote re-epithelialization and prevent wound progression, dehydration, and infection [Lloyd, 2012; Douglas, 2017].
  • Wound debridement may be needed to remove skin debris and necrotic tissue, which are potential sources of bacterial proliferation and infection [White, 2012; Douglas, 2017]. This also allows for more accurate assessment of burn depth [Butcher, 2012].
  • Blister and oedema management is important, as they can put pressure on the underlying dermis, can reduce skin perfusion, and potentially deepen burn injuries [Douglas, 2017].
  • There is limited and conflicting evidence in the literature on the use of topical antimicrobial agents for burn injuries.
    • Expert opinion in the international best practice guideline recommends considering their use for local wound infection [Wounds International, 2014].
    • Expert opinion in a review article is that deep dermal burns should be treated with a topical antimicrobial preparation (such as silver sulfadiazine [SSD]) to reduce pain, promote healing, and prevent wound desiccation, however it notes that newer occlusive dressings may be more clinically- and cost-effective [Lloyd, 2012].
    • A Cochrane systematic review on burn wound dressings found poor-quality evidence from 30 RCTs that SSD was consistently associated with poorer healing outcomes than newer occlusive dressings such as skin substitute, silver-containing, and silicon-coated dressings [Wasiak, 2013].
      • It noted, however, the lack of high-quality evidence on the effect of different dressings on wound healing, and a complete meta-analysis was not possible due to heterogeneity and risk of bias of the included studies.
    • A subsequent Cochrane systematic review of topical antiseptics for burns reviewed 56 RCTs (n = 5807) of primarily different antiseptic preparations compared with a topical antibiotic such as SSD [Norman, 2017].
      • It found no clear difference in the likelihood of healing between topical antiseptics and antibiotics, and there was very-low quality evidence that antiseptics were of unknown effectiveness in their ability to reduce the risk of infection compared with topical antibiotics or non-antimicrobial agents.
      • The data were generally of low- or very-low quality due to small sample sizes, low event rates, and often single studies analysing different comparators.
    • An additional Cochrane systematic review of 36 RCTs (n = 2117) found no evidence for the use of topical or systemic antibiotic prophylaxis in preventing burn wound infection [Barajas-Nava, 2013]. This finding is supported by the ISBI practice guidelines, which do not recommend the use of systemic prophylactic antibiotics for acute burns [ISBI, 2016].
Assessing the need for tetanus prophylaxis
  • This recommendation is based on the PHE document on tetanus [PHE, 2013].
    • Human tetanus immunoglobulin should be given to wounds that are considered to be at high-risk due to heavy contamination with material likely to contain tetanus spores, as this will give immediate protection against tetanus. Tetanus vaccine given at the time of injury may not boost immunity early enough to give sufficient protection within the incubation period of tetanus.
Arranging regular review until wound healing
  • The burn depth and complexity of injuries may increase within the first few days of a burn injury, due to progression of thermal injury, so frequent re-evaluation is necessary to identify wounds that are at increased risk of complications or which need specialist assessment [Lloyd, 2012; Wounds International, 2014].
  • Burn extent and depth may be more clearly demarcated after 72 hours following initial injury [Culleiton, 2013].
  • Superficial burns may produce a significant amount of exudate in the first 24–72 hours after injury due to increased capillary permeability, and this does not necessarily indicate wound infection [Butcher, 2012; Wounds International, 2014].
    • Increased levels of exudate should be managed with appropriate dressings, as this provides a portal for bacterial contamination if allowed to soak through dressings.
    • Following this initial time period, it may be necessary to reassess the optimal dressing choice as levels of exudate reduce.
Advice on skin care
  • The recommendation on the use of massage and emollient application is based on the fact that symptoms such as itch typically peak at 2–6 months after injury. It may also reduce the risk of hypertrophic scarring, which may occur 4–6 weeks after injury to the deep dermis [Cleland, 2012; Wounds International, 2014].
  • The recommendation on the use of high factor sunblock is based on the fact that newly healed epidermis may have increased melanocyte activity if exposed to sunlight following a burn injury, causing permanent hyperpigmentation [Douglas, 2017].
Arranging referral or seeking specialist advice
  • If a burn wound has not healed after 2–3 weeks, the burn may be deeper than thought at initial assessment and may need specialist management. Burns with prolonged healing times have an increased risk of hypertrophic scarring, and surgical intervention such as excision and grafting may be needed [Cleland, 2012; Wounds International, 2014].
  • Inadequate initial management of a superficial burn may allow it to progress to a deeper, more complex wound [Wounds International, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected wound infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If wound infection is suspected:

  • Arrange for the wound to be cleaned with 0.9% sodium chloride or lukewarm tap water. See the section on Wound management for more information.
  • Take a bacteriology swab from the burn wound and start empirical antibiotic treatment:
    • Prescribe oral flucloxacillin first-line for 7 days initially. If the person has a known penicillin allergy, prescribe oral clarithromycin.
    • See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for detailed prescribing information on doses, contraindications and cautions, adverse effects, and drug interactions of the different antibiotics.
    • Note: the routine use of topical antimicrobial agents is not recommended.
  • Offer analgesia for pain relief, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen, as needed. Consider adding in codeine for more severe pain, if appropriate. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information.
  • Arrange to review the person, the time interval depending on clinical judgement.
    • If symptoms are improving but have not fully resolved after 7 days of the first-line antibiotic, consider prescribing a further 7 days of treatment.
    • If there is little or no clinical response to the first-line antibiotic, switch the antibiotic depending on the sensitivities on the bacteriology swab result when available.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of wound infection are largely based on a Cochrane systematic review Antibiotic prophylaxis for preventing burn wound infection (Review) [Barajas-Nava, 2013] and expert opinion in a review article on management of infection in community-based burns [White, 2012].

  • Infection of burn injury wounds may increase the depth of tissue damage, delay healing, increase the risk of scarring, and cause life-threatening sepsis and other complications [White, 2012; Barajas-Nava, 2013].
  • The recommendation to take a bacteriological swab is based on the fact that this allows identification of causative micro-organisms and specific antibiotic sensitivities that can guide management [White, 2012].
  • CKS did not find good-quality evidence on specific antibiotic choices for the empirical treatment of infected non-complex burn wounds in primary care, and the antibiotic recommendations have been extrapolated from the management of cellulitis in primary care.
    • The recommendations to use broad-spectrum antibiotics has been based on the fact that burns may be infected with a wide variety of micro-organisms, such as Staphylococcus aureus, different Streptococcus species, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and anaerobic bacteria [White, 2012].
  • The recommendation to not use topical antimicrobial agents routinely is based on the fact that there is limited evidence for their efficacy, they are short-acting and have to be re-applied at least daily, and their use can lead to the build-up of discoloured material on the wound which makes reassessment difficult [White, 2012].
